title: Speech acts: Constative and performative - Colleen Glenney Boggs

multiple-choice.question: According to J. L. Austin, what is the difference between a constative and a performative?

options.label: A
options.text: A constative is a sentence that commands an action, while a performative is a sentence that describes something as true or false.

options.label: B
options.text: A constative is a sentence that describes something as true or false, while a performative is a sentence that denotes an action.

options.label: C
options.text: A constative is a sentence that denotes an action, while a performative is a sentence that describes something as true or false.

options.label: D
options.text: A constative is a sentence that is meant to inspire actions, while a performative is a sentence that conveys a message.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a performative sentence in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: "The park closes at 6 p.m."

options.label: B
options.text: "Recycle"

options.label: C
options.text: "I do"

options.label: D
options.text: "Heatwave!"

multiple-choice.question: What are felicity conditions, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The rules under which a constative can be enacted.

options.label: B
options.text: The rules under which a performative can be enacted.

options.label: C
options.text: The rules under which a speech act can be enacted.

options.label: D
options.text: The rules under which a sentence can be enacted.

multiple-choice.question: What happens if a performative sentence does not meet its felicity conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes a constative sentence.

options.label: B
options.text: It loses its power to denote action.

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes a speech act.

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes a sentence that conveys a message.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the result of a speech act such as "I do" in a wedding ceremony?

options.label: A
options.text: The couple is no longer married.

options.label: B
options.text: The couple is still unmarried.

options.label: D
options.text: The couple is in a state of uncertainty.

title: The most groundbreaking scientist you've never heard of - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Who is Nicolas Steno, and what is he known for in the field of geology?

options.label: A
options.text: He is a geologist who discovered the concept of plate tectonics.

options.label: B
options.text: He is a Danish anatomist who expanded and connected the concepts of Earth, life, and understanding.

options.label: C
options.text: He is a paleontologist who discovered the first dinosaur fossil.

options.label: D
options.text: He is a geologist who developed the theory of uniformitarianism.

multiple-choice.question: What was Nicolas Steno's method of scientific inquiry, and how did it contribute to his discoveries?

options.label: A
options.text: He relied on ancient texts, Aristotelian metaphysics, and Cartesian deductions to inform his research.

options.label: B
options.text: He emphasized empirical, experimental evidence and refused to let speculation or rationalization overrule it.

options.label: C
options.text: He used only mathematical models to understand geological processes.

options.label: D
options.text: He relied on intuition and personal experience to guide his research.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Nicolas Steno's discovery of the duct in animal skulls that sends saliva to the mouth?

options.label: A
options.text: It disproved the theory of evolution and showed that humans are unique in their anatomy.

options.label: B
options.text: It refuted Descartes' idea that only humans had a pineal gland and showed that it was a shared feature among species.

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the development of a new theory of gravity.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the field of anatomy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of uniformitarianism, and how did Nicolas Steno contribute to its development?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the idea that the past was shaped by processes that are not observable today.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the idea that the past was shaped by processes observable today.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the idea that the Earth was created in its current form 6000 years ago.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the idea that the Earth is still forming today.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of Nicolas Steno's maxim, "The pursuit of the beauty of the as yet unknown"?

options.label: A
options.text: It emphasizes the importance of seeking truth beyond our senses and current understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: It highlights the importance of relying on ancient texts and traditional knowledge.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that the pursuit of knowledge is only important for practical applications.

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that the unknown is inherently beautiful and worth pursuing.

title: Was Leonardo da Vinci dyslexic?

multiple-choice.question: Why did Leonardo da Vinci write in a mirror way, according to the movie?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was trying to create a deliberate form of code.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he was left-handed and wanted to avoid smudging his ink.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he was dyslexic and it was easier for him to write in a mirror way.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was trying to create a unique artistic style.

multiple-choice.question: What is the theory proposed by Professor Maryanne Wolf about Leonardo da Vinci's mirror writing?

options.label: A
options.text: That he was trying to create a code to hide his messages.

options.label: B
options.text: That he was left-handed and it was easier for him to write in a mirror way.

options.label: C
options.text: That he was dyslexic and his brain was wired to write in a mirror way.

options.label: D
options.text: That he was trying to create a unique artistic style.

multiple-choice.question: What is dyslexia, according to Professor Maryanne Wolf?

options.label: A
options.text: A learning disability that impairs people's ability to recognize sequences of words and letters.

options.label: B
options.text: A learning disability that impairs people's ability to analyze space and geometrical shapes and forms.

options.label: C
options.text: An inherited learning disability that impairs people's reading and writing skills.

options.label: D
options.text: A learning disability that impairs people's ability to communicate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of Professor Maryanne Wolf's experiment with four people?

options.label: A
options.text: To test the theory that left-handed people are better at mirror writing.

options.label: B
options.text: To test the theory that dyslexics are better at mirror writing.

options.label: C
options.text: To test the theory that mirror writing is easier for left-handed and dyslexic people.

options.label: D
options.text: To test the theory that mirror writing is a deliberate form of code.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of Professor Maryanne Wolf's experiment with four people?

options.label: A
options.text: The dyslexics were slower than the others and the right-handers were faster than the left-handers.

options.label: B
options.text: The left-handers were slower than the others and the right-handers were faster than the left-handers.

options.label: C
options.text: The dyslexics were quicker than the others and the left-handers were faster than the right-handers.

options.label: D
options.text: The experiment showed no significant differences between the groups.

title: The game layer on top of the world - Seth Priebatsch

multiple-choice.question: According to Seth Prentice, what is the main difference between the social layer and the game layer of the internet?

options.label: A
options.text: The social layer is about adding a social fabric to the web, while the game layer is about influencing behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: The social layer is about building connections, while the game layer is about building communities.

options.label: C
options.text: The social layer is about using forces to manipulate behavior, while the game layer is about using incentives to influence behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: The social layer is about building frameworks, while the game layer is about building games.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the first game Dynamic that Seth Prentice discusses in his presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: The appointment Dynamic

options.label: B
options.text: The influence and Status Dynamic

options.label: C
options.text: The progression Dynamic

options.label: D
options.text: The communal Discovery Dynamic

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the appointment Dynamic is used in a conventional game?

options.label: A
options.text: In Farmville, where players have to water their crops at a certain time to prevent them from wilting.

options.label: B
options.text: In Modern Warfare, where players have to level up to unlock new badges and status symbols.

options.label: C
options.text: In World of Warcraft, where players have to complete quests and challenges to level up and unlock new rewards.

options.label: D
options.text: In LinkedIn, where users have to complete their profiles to 100% to unlock new features.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the company that created a product to help people take their medicine on time using the appointment Dynamic?

options.label: A
options.text: Scavenger

options.label: B
options.text: Vitality

options.label: C
options.text: Facebook

options.label: D
options.text: Princeton University

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the communal Discovery Dynamic is used in a real-world scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: In the DARPA balloon challenge, where a group of people from MIT used a network to find hidden balloons across the United States.

options.label: B
options.text: In the game of Monopoly, where players try to find Boardwalk by completing challenges and collecting rewards.

options.label: C
options.text: In the game of Farmville, where players try to find the best crops by completing challenges and collecting rewards.

options.label: D
options.text: In the game of World of Warcraft, where players try to find the best loot by completing quests and challenges.

title: The true power of the performing arts - Ben Cameron

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's central passion in life?

options.label: A
options.text: Their love for the live professional performing arts.

options.label: B
options.text: Their passion for Judge Judy.

options.label: C
options.text: Their interest in technology and its impact on the arts.

options.label: D
options.text: Their love for reading.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the biggest competitor for leisure time in today's society?

options.label: A
options.text: Television.

options.label: B
options.text: Video games.

options.label: C
options.text: C: The Internet.

options.label: D
options.text: Social media.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of the Internet on the cultural market, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: It has led to a decrease in audience numbers and a decrease in the number of arts participants.

options.label: B
options.text: It has led to a massive redefinition of the cultural market, with a time when anyone is a potential author.

options.label: C
options.text: It has led to a decrease in the number of arts institutions and a decrease in the number of professional artists.

options.label: D
options.text: It has led to a decrease in the number of arts participants, but an increase in the number of arts institutions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the rise of, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The professional artist who works primarily in the concert hall or on the stage.

options.label: B
options.text: The amateur artist who works primarily in the concert hall or on the stage.

options.label: C
options.text: The professional hybrid artist who works on issues such as women's rights, human rights, and global warming.

options.label: D
options.text: The traditional arts institution.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the impact of the arts on local economies?

options.label: A
options.text: Every dollar spent on a performing arts ticket generates one additional dollar for the local economy.

options.label: B
options.text: Every dollar spent on a performing arts ticket generates five to seven additional dollars for the local economy.

options.label: C
options.text: The arts have no impact on local economies.

options.label: D
options.text: The arts are a burden on local economies.

title: A trip through space to calculate distance - Heather Tunnell

multiple-choice.question: Bleebop and Mark are competing in a space race to the moon, starting from different asteroids. How far is Bleebop's asteroid from the moon?

options.label: A
options.text: 100 miles

options.label: B
options.text: 150 miles

options.label: C
options.text: 240 miles

options.label: D
options.text: 300 miles

multiple-choice.question: Mark's rocket arrives at the moon in 2 hours. What is the rate of Mark's rocket?

options.label: A
options.text: 60 miles per hour

options.label: B
options.text: 75 miles per hour

options.label: C
options.text: 80 miles per hour

options.label: D
options.text: 100 miles per hour

options.label: A
options.text: Distance

options.label: B
options.text: Time

options.label: C
options.text: Rate

options.label: D
options.text: Unknown

options.label: A
options.text: 1 hour

options.label: B
options.text: 2 hours

options.label: C
options.text: 3 hours

options.label: D
options.text: 4 hours

options.label: A
options.text: Distance and speed

options.label: B
options.text: Time and rate

options.label: C
options.text: Rate and distance

options.label: D
options.text: Speed and time

title: Cicadas: The dormant army beneath your feet - Rose Eveleth

multiple-choice.question: How often do cicadas emerge from the ground to molt, mate, and die?

options.label: A
options.text: Every 5 years

options.label: B
options.text: Every 10 years

options.label: C
options.text: Every 13 or 17 years

options.label: D
options.text: Every 20 years

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why cicadas emerge in such large numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: To find food

options.label: B
options.text: To escape predators

options.label: C
options.text: To overwhelm predators and ensure survival

options.label: D
options.text: To migrate to a new location

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the fungus Massospora that infects cicadas?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide cicadas with nutrients

options.label: B
options.text: To protect cicadas from predators

options.label: C
options.text: To infect cicadas and release spores

options.label: D
options.text: To help cicadas communicate with each other

multiple-choice.question: Why do cicadas emerge in large numbers every 13 or 17 years, rather than more or less frequently?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a natural part of their life cycle

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a response to environmental factors

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's a way to avoid predators

options.label: D
options.text: Because the exact reason is unknown

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical lifespan of a cicada after it emerges from the ground?

options.label: A
options.text: Several months

options.label: B
options.text: A few weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Several years

options.label: D
options.text: A lifetime

title: Why do Americans and Canadians celebrate Labor Day? - Kenneth C. Davis

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of Labor Day, celebrated in the United States and Canada on the first Monday of every September?

options.label: A
options.text: To honor the end of the Industrial Revolution

options.label: B
options.text: To celebrate the beginning of the Great Depression

options.label: C
options.text: To recognize the hard work and efforts of workers

options.label: D
options.text: To commemorate the Haymarket Square Riot of 1886

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the violent Haymarket Square Riot of 1886?

options.label: A
options.text: A dispute between workers and business owners over wages

options.label: B
options.text: A protest against the execution of four union leaders

options.label: C
options.text: A clash between workers and the police over a labor strike

options.label: D
options.text: A riot sparked by a speech given by a union leader

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the violent railroad strike in 1894, which resulted in the death of several people?

options.label: A
options.text: The strike was successful, and workers gained better wages and working conditions

options.label: B
options.text: The strike was ended, and President Grover Cleveland sent 12,000 soldiers to maintain order

options.label: C
options.text: The strike was called off, and workers agreed to return to work without concessions

options.label: D
options.text: The strike was forgotten, and workers continued to work long hours without benefits

multiple-choice.question: What law was signed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1938, which called for an eight-hour work day, a five-day work week, and an end to child labor?

options.label: A
options.text: The Fair Labor Standards Act

options.label: B
options.text: The Child Labor Act

options.label: C
options.text: The Eight-Hour Work Day Act

options.label: D
options.text: The Labor Union Act

multiple-choice.question: Why was the original September date for Labor Day kept, rather than adopting the May 1st date used by many labor and political groups around the world?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid conflicting with other holidays

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid the more radical associations of May 1st

options.label: C
options.text: To honor the Haymarket Square Riot of 1886

options.label: D
options.text: To commemorate the execution of four union leaders

title: The limit does not exist

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea that the speaker is trying to convey to the contestants?

options.label: A
options.text: That solving math problems is easy.

options.label: B
options.text: That focusing on others' flaws won't help you achieve your goals.

options.label: C
options.text: That math is not important in real life is.

options.label: D
options.text: That the limit of the equation is the most important thing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the equation if the limit never approaches anything?

options.label: A
options.text: The limit is negative one.

options.label: B
options.text: The limit does not exist.

options.label: C
options.text: The limit is positive one.

options.label: D
options.text: The limit is zero.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: Mrs. Johnson.

options.label: C
options.text: Mr. Smith.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The contestants are eliminated, and the competition is over.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The Higgs Field, explained - Don Lincoln

multiple-choice.question: What is the Higgs Field thought to give mass to?

options.label: A
options.text: Fundamental, subatomic particles like atoms and molecules

options.label: B
options.text: Fundamental, subatomic particles like quarks and leptons

options.label: C
options.text: All types of particles, including photons

options.label: D
options.text: Only particles that interact with the Higgs Field

multiple-choice.question: What is the Higgs boson compared to in the analogy of the party?

options.label: A
options.text: A tax collector who doesn't interact with the crowd

options.label: B
options.text: A clump in the crowd that moves across the room

options.label: C
options.text: A physicist who is very popular and interacts strongly with the crowd

options.label: D
options.text: A rumor that spreads across the room

multiple-choice.question: According to the analogy, why do some particles have mass while others do not?

options.label: A
options.text: Because some particles are more popular than others

options.label: B
options.text: Because some particles interact more with the Higgs Field

options.label: C
options.text: Because some particles interact with the Higgs Field and others do not

options.label: D
options.text: Because some particles are heavier than others

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the analogy used to explain the Higgs Field and the Higgs boson?

options.label: A
options.text: That the Higgs Field is a physical force that pushes particles apart

options.label: B
options.text: That the Higgs boson is a particle that gives mass to other particles

options.label: C
options.text: That mass comes from interactions with a field, and the Higgs boson is a clump in the field

options.label: D
options.text: That the Higgs Field is a type of energy that is released when particles interact

multiple-choice.question: What was the prize offered to physicists who could come up with a simple explanation of the Higgs Field?

options.label: A
options.text: A year's worth of funding for their research

options.label: B
options.text: A bottle of quality champagne

options.label: C
options.text: A Nobel Prize in Physics

options.label: D
options.text: A trip to the CERN laboratory

title: The army ants of Africa

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean to be a Native American?

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They were known for their skills in fishing.

options.label: D
options.text: They were known for their skills in warfare.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of grapefruits.

options.label: D
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of baseballs.

options.label: A
options.text: Darwin knew that every country had a form of pigeons.

options.label: B

options.text: The size of a fingertip

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Gravity and the human body - Jay Buckey

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the bone and muscle mass of a person who is in weightlessness for a long period of time?

options.label: A
options.text: They tend to gain bone and muscle mass.

options.label: B
options.text: They tend to lose bone and muscle mass.

options.label: C
options.text: They tend to stay the same.

options.label: D
options.text: They tend to change in a way that is not predictable.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people tend to lose bone and muscle mass in weightlessness?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their bodies are not used to being in space.

options.label: B
options.text: Because their bodies are adapting to the lack of gravity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their bodies are trying to conserve energy.

options.label: D
options.text: Because their bodies are not able to function properly.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the balance system of a person who is in weightlessness for a long period of time?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes more sensitive.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes less sensitive.

options.label: C
options.text: It changes in a way that is not predictable.

options.label: D
options.text: It stays the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a person who grows up on Earth and a person who grows up in space?

options.label: A
options.text: The person who grows up in space has a stronger sense of balance.

options.label: B
options.text: The person who grows up in space has a weaker sense of balance.

options.label: C
options.text: The person who grows up in space has a fundamentally different brain.

options.label: D
options.text: The person who grows up in space has a different heart.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of an experiment where a kitten is raised with a patch over one eye?

options.label: A
options.text: The kitten can see out of both eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: The kitten can see out of the eye that was patched.

options.label: C
options.text: The kitten can't see out of the eye that was patched.

options.label: D
